items.title: [The Guardian Global Development] Floating cities of logs: can the ‚Äòlungs of Africa‚Äô survive its exploitation?
items.content_html:
The Congo River basin is one of the planet‚Äôs most biodiverse ecosystems. But it is also home to a growing population and relentless trade in timber and charcoal

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt be scared of the storms,‚Äù says Jean de Dieu Mokuma as the sun sets on the Congo River behind him. ‚ÄúWith the current, once your voyage has begun, there is no turning back.‚Äù Mokuma, along with his wife Marie-Therese and their two young children, is piloting a cargo of timber downstream lashed on to a precarious raft and tied to a canoe.

Families wake up at dawn on rafts of logs and merchandise that are being transported down the Congo River by boat to Kinshasa, the DRC capital

items.title: [New Atlas] Kia's 1st tiny camper van rolls out in slick, IKEA-like setup from USA
items.content_html:
Ever since Kia looked into the crystal ball of off-road mini-camping with its epic, little PV5 WKNDR concept, the world has waited patiently to see what it would drum up as a retail camper van built aboard its highly flexible Platform Beyond Vehicle (PBV) EV architecture. It waits no more. While Kia has not (yet) developed a fully integrated PBV camper van, it has introduced an officially branded camper kit for the PV5 electric van, which itself launched just a few months ago. Interestingly, the flat-pack IKEA-like (I-Kia?) assemble-yourself kit was developed in the USA, which has not even been confirmed as a PV5 market.

Continue Reading

Category: Campervans, Adventure Vehicles, Outdoors

Tags: mini-campervan, Campervan, camper-in-a-box, RV, Kia, Camping, Modular, electric-camper, Outdoors and Camping
